The six sense bases have already been explained in the form aggregate, only the remaining unmanifest [form] will now be explained.
Verse:
Disturbed mind, mindless states, etc., flowing along with purity and impurity,
The nature of the great elements and their derivatives, thus unmanifest [form] is explained.
Discussion:
Disturbed mind, mindless states, etc. The word etc. refers to both places, namely the undisturbed mind and the state of having mind.
Unwholesome and indeterminate are called disturbed mind, other minds are called undisturbed.
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation are called mindless, because they can extinguish the mind.
Although there are other states without mind, unmanifest form does not flow along with them, therefore the word mindless does not include them.
It is called flowing along because it continues in similarity in the three natures of mind and in the state without mind.
Pure and impure means good and bad.
That which arises simultaneously with a good mind is called pure non-manifest action. Its similar continuity is called restraint or non-restraint.
That which arises simultaneously with a bad mind is called impure non-manifest action. Its similar continuity is called non-restraint or not non-restraint.
If it is a neutral mind, it also gives rise to both kinds of non-manifest action in a single moment. Therefore, it is said that the mind that gives rise to both is a neutral mind.
However, the mind that accompanies pure and impure non-manifest action may not be similar.
If pure non-manifest action has no mind at all, the mind that gives rise to it is similar in both cases.
It has already been explained that pure and impure [non-manifest action] flows along with a distracted mind or a mindless state.
It is also said to be derived from the great elements. There is another kind of pure and impure [non-manifest action] that flows along. In order to distinguish it, the word form is used.
Here, derived means the meaning of cause of manifestation.
How do we know this?
As a sutra says:
Form is the cause of my view.
This means that the view of self arises based on form.

It is said that this is called non-indicative because it is the pure or impure form that arises from the power of wholesome or unwholesome minds, etc., and although it is like indicative form, it does not indicate and make others understand, therefore it is called non-indicative.ğŸ”½In order to show the reason for establishing this name, it is said that this is called non-indicative because it is the pure or impure form that arises from the power of wholesome or unwholesome minds, etc.
The author of the commentary does not accept this kind of non-indicative form, therefore he says by this it is said.

To summarize, the wholesome or unwholesome form that arises from the distinctions in the indicative form of body and speech, and from the distinctions in wholesome or unwholesome minds, etc., without obstruction, is called non-indicative.
The author of the commentary is now unable to fully explain the characteristics of non-indicative form in this verse, because he says that it is called non-indicative because it flows along.
He himself explains:

A similar continuity is called following the flow, but the first moment cannot be called a continuity, lest there be the fault of overextension. Therefore, the first moment of non-manifest action definitely does not enter the characteristics that are explained.
Moreover, continuity is a provisional reality, not a real one. Non-manifest action is not real, and this contradicts the tenets of the Abhidharma.
Moreover, that which is emitted by concentration is not in a state of distraction and no-thought, and does not follow the flow, so it should not be non-manifest action.
If it is said that in a state of non-distraction and thought, it follows the flow, so there is no fault, then pure and impure manifest actions should have the characteristics of non-manifest action.
Moreover, if it is said that the word etc. includes no-thought, this word has no use, because it is already included.
The word etc. in distracted mind, etc. already includes all other states with thought. What does the second etc. include?

The Sutra master should consider this. If it is said that the latter etc. includes non-distracted mind, and the former is useless, this is not so, because it is not possible to include it. How is it possible for the latter etc. to include non-distracted mind?
The principle of prohibition arises in similar situations, but the principle of non-arising, etc. does not apply to other cases, so it is not completely included.
Or else, confused speech becomes useless.
Moreover, one should distinguish and say that only pure avijÃ±apti flows along in the state of no-mind, not the other. In one's own explanation, one also does not make a distinction.
Therefore, the master of the sutra should consider this principle. How does one explain the characteristics of avijÃ±apti without error?
Action and so forth, other minds and so forth, and in the state of no-mind, there is indication.
Unimpeded, derivative nature, this is called avijÃ±apti-rÅ«pa.
AvijÃ±apti has already been explained.
Here, what is called the great elements and the derivative form, what are the great elements?
Verse:
The great elements are called the four elements, namely earth, water, fire, and wind.
They can accomplish the functions of supporting and so forth, with the natures of solidity, moisture, heat, and movement.
Treatise:
Why are these great elements called elements?
Because they are the source of all form dharmas.
They also originate from the great elements. The places where they originate are called elements in the world, just as gold and other ores are called gold and other elements.
Or they are called elements because they are the places where various sufferings originate, as explained before.
Some say:
They are called elements because they can support the self-characteristics of the great elements and the derivative form. These elements are also called great elements.
Why are they called elements?
What is meant by great?
When various derivative forms arise with distinctions, they can give rise to those distinctions of various kinds, and therefore they are called elements.
Some say:
Because of the dominant influence of the karma of sentient beings, they have never been nonexistent since beginningless birth and death, and therefore they are called elements.
Or the appearance of dharmas is called existence. They give rise to the nature of existence, and therefore they are called elements.
This means the principle of the arising of the nature of existence of dharmas, or the principle of the arising of the bodies of sentient beings.
Or it is called â€œgreatâ€ because it can manifest the ten kinds of created form, because they are manifested by its power.
If this is so, then there is the great fault that all conditions have a function in the generation of results.
There is no great fault, because there is a great function.

The great function is that among the fundamental activities of sentient beings, these four have a superior function. On the basis of them, consciousness and space are established and can be said to be the fundamental activities of sentient beings. In order to distinguish them from the rest, they are called great.
Also, among the activities that deceive and delude fools, these four are the most excellent, and therefore they are called great.
Just as among thieves who deceive, those whose activities are superior are distinguished from the rest and are called great thieves.
In the same way, among the four conditions, these are superior and are called great, distinguishing them from the rest, without the fault of too much extension.
Some say:
These four are universally the support of all other form, and because they are extensive, they are called great.
Some say:
Because solidity, etc., exist in all aggregates of form, etc., they are called great.

In the aggregate in which wind predominates, form, etc., are lacking. In the aggregate in which fire predominates, taste, etc., are lacking. In the aggregates of the realm of form, smell and taste are lacking. In the aggregate of blue, yellow, etc., are lacking. In the aggregate of smoothness, etc., roughness, etc., are lacking. Sound, etc., are not fixed. Therefore only these four are called great.
Why is space not called a great element?
Because the characteristics of a great element are not established in it.
Great elements are so called because they are able to injure or benefit. Space is not so, and therefore it is not a great element.
Isnâ€™t it the case that space is able to injure or benefit because it contains and receives?
In reality, space has no function of containing and receiving. It is not the case that form that can be aggregated opens up and makes way for space in the direction in which it is located.
How does it contain and receive?
However, because it is unimpeded, it does not obstruct their existence.
Therefore space has no function of injuring or benefiting.
If this is so, why is it said,
â€œIt is called space because it contains and receivesâ€?

This explanation of the term means that because there is space, resistant bodies are able to interpenetrate. Space is similar to space in that it is a small part of space. Therefore, this place is provisionally called space.
The space element is the cavity of the throat and so on, which enables sentient beings to swallow food and drink and to defecate and urinate.
Because it does not have the function of receiving harm or benefit, therefore space definitely is not a primary element.
Moreover, the primary elements are not one and are not permanent. Their self-natures are numerous, and their effects are innumerable.

The self-nature of space is one and is permanent. Its characteristics are without distinction. It is completely without effects. It is not that there are no separate causes that produce separate effects. Therefore space is not called a primary element.

If you say that because the other causes have distinctions, they are able to assist space in producing separate effects, then these separate causes are able to produce separate effects. What use is there in positing space as a cause?
There is an opinion.
Because the nature of space is permanent, the characteristics of dharmas in the states of arising and cessation are not different.
Earth and so forth are not like this, and therefore dharmas are not the same.
It is presently seen that the characteristics of the primary elements change in the states of seeds and so forth, and sprouts and so forth arise.
Unconditioned space is not like this, because its nature and characteristics are permanent, and therefore it has no activity at all. Since it cannot produce, it is not a primary element.
Moreover, in this context, because the words â€œprimaryâ€ and â€œelementâ€ are both used, the meaning is established as only four.
Space has the meaning of being primary but not the meaning of being an element, because the name â€œelementâ€ is a synonym for that which can produce.
Some say:
Space also has no meaning of being primary, because its substance is not form.
Form and other conditioned non-form can produce, and therefore are elements but not primary.

As explained above, the two meanings of the primary elements are not established for each other, and because if either one is lacking, they cannot produce the derivative form, therefore the primary elements are only four, neither more nor less.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say this:
If there were less, they would not be able to perform their functions; if there were more, they would be useless. Therefore there are only four, like the legs of a bed or chair.
Some say:
The four great elements are by nature only four.
Some say:

The four great elements require only four functions in relation to derivative form: support, cohesion, ripening, and expansion. If there were less or more, they would be unable to perform their functions.
How do we know that these four great elements are always inseparable?
Because it should be understood from the Sutra on Entering the Womb and the Sutra on the Great Elements.
And it must be so.

What is the reason?ğŸ”½It is because in things like stone, the three functions of absorbing, increasing, and falling are found, and therefore we know that water, fire, and wind are always inseparable in it.
In all waters, the three functions of supporting, absorbing, and flowing are found, and therefore we know that earth, fire, and wind are always inseparable in it.
In the flame, the three activities of supporting, gathering, and striking are perceived. Therefore, we know that in this flame, earth, water, and wind are always inseparable.
In the mass of wind, the three activities of supporting, producing, and touching cold and warm are perceived. Therefore, we know that in this wind, earth, water, and fire are always inseparable.
How do we know that there are these four elements?
Because of this, they always follow each other, and because of this, they can accomplish the activities of supporting and so forth.
That is to say, the elements of earth and so forth can respectively accomplish the four kinds of activities of supporting, gathering, ripening, and expanding.

Because of this, in the aggregates of form, if the four activities of supporting and so forth are perceived, we know that in this there are the elements of earth and so forth, mutually inseparable, always following each other.
Are the four activities of supporting and so forth the specific characteristics of the elements?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
These four elements, in order, take solidity, moisture, heat, and motion as their specific characteristics.

You should know that in this context, nature is used to indicate substance, because it is explained that substance and nature are inseparable.ğŸ”½How should one understand that the four kinds of earth, etc., which are different from the characteristics of solidity, etc., have the functions of supporting, etc.?
How should one understand that the characteristics and functions of the four kinds of earth, etc., are not different, and that they are investigated as different?
Because we do not see any difference between characteristics and functions.

We do not see any difference between the characteristics of solidity, etc., and the functions of supporting, etc., so we investigate you in return, asking whether you say that apart from the characteristics of solidity, etc., there is a separate function of supporting, etc.

However, the function of supporting, etc., is neither separate from nor identical with the characteristics of solidity, etc. Solidity, etc., are precisely the specific characteristics of earth, etc., because there is nothing to be observed.

The function of supporting, etc., has something else to be observed and is therefore established. It is not the specific characteristic of supporting that is referred to as the function of supporting.
Do not let it be the case that because all dharmas have the function of supporting, they are all called earth, resulting in the error of over-extension.

Therefore, you should know that the characteristic of solidity of the earth element has nothing else to be observed. It is said to have the function of supporting because it is observed as that which is supported.
The water element has the characteristic of wetness, and there is no separate object of observation. The separate observation is said to include the function of embracing.
The fire element has the characteristic of heat, and there is no separate object of observation. The separate observation is said to include the function of ripening what is to be ripened.
The wind element has the characteristic of movement, and there is no separate object of observation. The separate observation is said to include the function of nourishing the kalala, etc.
Or it is said that the function of nourishing refers to the sprouts, etc. Nourishing means increasing or flowing and attracting.
Movement means being able to attract the primary elements and form, causing their continuity to be born and reaching other places.
Therefore, the functions of holding, etc. are not the same as the characteristics of solidity, etc.
Some say:
Because the three times and one time are different, it is known that the meaning of characteristics and functions is not the same.
Some say:
Earth, etc. have the functions of holding, etc. If the earth element, etc. have the characteristics of solidity, etc.
This is not so, because wind and the wind element are no different, and length and movement should be one.
If wind is by nature movement, why do the scriptures and the Abhidharma treatise all say that the wind element is lightness and movement, and also say that lightness is a derivative form?
Saying that movement is wind and lightness is derivative form shows their specific characteristics.
Lightness is wind, and this indicates that it is a cause by showing its effect, because lightness is the effect of wind.
Isnâ€™t the fire element also a cause of lightness, since it is said that lightness is produced by the increase of fire and wind?
Although this is said, fire is not definite. If there is lightness whose cause is the increase of fire, then there must be an increase of the wind element there.

Or there may be lightness whose cause is the increase of wind, and yet there may be no increase of the fire element there, just as the lightness of the petals of the lotus flower is carried by the wind.
In this case, if the fire element increases, then there must be heat there that can be apprehended.
Therefore the wind element is universally the cause of lightness, and so lightness is specially mentioned and is used to reveal the wind element.

However, the characteristics of earth, etc., are easy to understand, so it is not necessary to explain the results of heaviness, etc. The movement of earth, etc., is difficult to understand in comparison with the other three characteristics of solidity, etc.
Are the elements of earth, etc., just earth, etc.?ğŸ”½No.
What then?
The verse states:
Earth is said to be the visible and shaped colors, named according to worldly conventions.
Water and fire are also the same. Wind is just the element itself.
The treatise states:
The word earth only indicates the visible and shaped color realms.
Isn't earth a composite of the four realms? Why is it only said that the visible and shaped are earth?

Although there are the realms of smell, taste, and touch in this [earth], it is said in accordance with worldly conventions. This is because when people in the world indicate earth, they indicate it with visible and shaped colors.

If that is so, the world also indicates clothes, etc., with visible and shaped [colors] to make them known. For example, saying clothes, etc., are white, long, etc. But it is accepted that clothes, etc., are the nature of the four realms. Earth should also be the same. Why is it only color?
Moreover, the world also establishes the name earth for smells, etc., saying:
I now smell earth, taste earth, and touch earth.
Although this is so, form and shape are clearly expressed by earth, water, and fire.
Why is this?

The world does not often say I smell water, nor does it often say I smell taste in fire. Although it is said one touches earth, etc., it is the elements of earth, etc. Therefore, although smells, etc. exist in earth, form and shape are superior and are mentioned first.
Moreover, form and shape clearly express the two elements, earth, etc., without distinction, and therefore they are mentioned first.
If that is so, since form and shape are superior to smells, etc. in expressing clothes, etc., they should also be mentioned first.
The names given rise to by the world are not fixed, and therefore the Abhidharma masters, following the names given rise to by the world, show the distinctions of earth, etc. and clothes, etc.

Moreover, real entities that are not commonly recognized in the world are all conventionally existent. Therefore, with regard to conventional phenomena, one should speak in accordance with the distinctions in conceptualization and names that arise in the world. Thus, it is also without error to conventionally speak of fragrance, etc. as earth.
Moreover, this is said with reference to earth that is manifested in visible form and shape.
Because the conceptualization and names of the world are not fixed, one cannot take one case as an example and say that all are the same.
It has been said that the four sense bases of clothing, etc. have form as their nature. The remaining general dharmas should be understood as appropriate.
Within things such as clothing, there is also birth, etc. Those things should have the five sense bases as their nature.
Although they are not nonexistent, the world does not give rise to the conceptualization and names of clothing, etc. with regard to them.
If that is so, the sense base of sound should be called clothing, etc., because the world speaks of hearing the sound of clothing, etc.
Although there is also sound, it is not continuous. Form, etc. always exist, and therefore only the four are mentioned.
Just as earth only uses visible form and shape as its essence, so it is with water and fire, following worldly conceptualization.
The world directly perceives water, blue, long, etc., and therefore says that the revealing form of water is the intrinsic nature of water.
The world sees and touches the flowing appearance of water and then says,
Here is the flow of water.
However, the substance of this flow is not really water, because the objects of the five sense organs are each different;
it is also not revealing form, because it can be touched by the body;
and it is also not shape, because it is not included in the eight [types of form].
How can one see and touch the flowing appearance of water if there is no separate form realm apart from revealing and shape?
The wind power pushes the aggregation of many waters, producing them in different places, and they continue in succession. The world gives rise to the notion of flow with regard to this.

When the many waters are born in different places, the revealing and shape within them are seen by the eyes, and the wet nature within them is touched by the body. Therefore, the revealing, shape, and wet nature, struck by the wind power and pushed in succession, are said to be the nature of flow when born in different places. Apart from this, there is no separate substance of flow. Therefore, the flow of water, etc., is a provisional reality and not a true reality.

Because fire is seen in the world as red and long, etc., it is said that the self-nature of fire is manifested in form. Moreover, when color and touch transform and arise, it is called flame, charcoal, etc.
This is provisional, not real, because no real substance is obtained by the body or eyes.
The difference between earth, etc., and the elements has already been explained.
Because the world establishes wind based on movement, wind and the wind element are not distinguished. For this reason, it is said that wind is the same as the element.
Isn't it that the world also has the notion of wind towards manifested form and shape? Because the world presently points to black wind and lump wind to each other.
There is a general explanation for this difficulty, therefore it is said also.
This is the meaning of the difference between earth, etc., and the elements, which ancient masters all say:
Earth is mixed in it, therefore it is seen like this.
In order to manifest that wind is precisely the wind element, it is said again so. So means the definition.
Among these two explanations, the former is superior, because the universal and impurity are not distinguished, and because impurity only takes form as its object.
The verse says:
Herein, the faculties and objects are called the ten bases and ten elements.
The treatise says:

It has already been said that the nature of the form aggregate is real entities, faculties, objects, and unmanifest form. Herein, the faculties and objects are also called the ten bases and ten elements.
In the category of bases, they are established as the ten bases, namely the eye base, etc.
In the category of elements, they are established as the ten elements, namely the eye element, etc.
The form aggregate has already been established, and the bases and elements have also been established.
What is the reason for calling this the form aggregate?
The teachings of the Well-Gone One say that it is called form because it changes and decays.

This means that because it is the cause of painful feelings, because it has contact, and because it can be transformed and changed, it is called changing and decaying. Because it changes and decays, it is called form.
As for being the cause of painful feelings, form that changes and decays can give rise to painful feelings. As the Meaning Chapter says:
People who pursue desires always give rise to hopes.
If their desires are not fulfilled, they are tormented as if struck by an arrow.
That which is contacted is that which is contacted by hands, etc., and the form that is then changed and destroyed is the meaning of being obstructed and changeable.
That which can be changed is like the bodies of cows, sheep, etc., which can be changed. This is the meaning of being changeable and exchangeable, because it can be changed, it is called changeable.
How can form be changed?
It is called changeable because it arises with different characteristics.
Or it is called form because it can express the karma that was practiced in the past, as a sutra says:
This, Brahmin!
The karma that can lead to an ugly form, namely much anger and resentment.
Or it is called form because it can express what exists internally, as a sutra says:
Venerable One!
Your faculties are now clear and joyful, you will surely realize the nectar.
Isn't this explanation of the word form only in terms of form that is seen and counted by sentient beings? Only this can express the karma that was practiced in the past and the internal mind.
If this is so, then the formless, non-sentient dharmas should all be non-form.
There is no such fault, because only in the aggregate of form does this meaning exist. It is not said that all forms are able to indicate.
Moreover, in all the non-form aggregates there is nothing that can indicate, therefore this explanation is logically established. As a sutra says:
Karma is the cause of birth.
This says that all births have karma as their cause, but it does not say that all karmas are the cause of birth. Now one should not argue that karma that is not the cause of birth is not karma.
If it were not so, then the words of the Well-Gone One could also be argued against, because not all forms are subject to change and destruction.
The World-Honored One spoke thus based on form that is obstructive.
Because it is subject to change and destruction, it is called form.
He also said:
Who can change and destroy it?
Because it is touched by the hand, it is immediately changed and destroyed, and so on at length.
He also said:
For those who indulge in desires, there is no evil karma that is not done.

But it is not the case that saints do not cultivate desires at all, and yet they do not commit evil actions that would lead to bad destinies. Therefore we know that the above explanation refers only to ordinary beings.
This is also so, and it cannot be used as a difficulty.
Or, all form can indicate karma cultivated in the past. The form of sentient beings is also commonly accepted as the result of past karma. Therefore, how can formless form indicate it?
How can formless form indicate it?
Because it is not separate from form with visible appearance. There is no form with visible appearance apart from formless form.
Because form with visible appearance and formless form are the results of the same karma. For this reason, it is established that formless form can indicate meaning.

But it also establishes the error that feeling, etc. are form, because although they arise from karma, they are not always present, and even if they were always present, they are subtle and difficult to know.
Form born of retribution does not arise from thought, and does not immediately follow and continue. Therefore only form has the ability to indicate karma cultivated in the past.
If that is so, since sound is not born of retribution, it should not be form.
Although it is not born from action, it can manifest the action that was cultivated in a previous life, just as salt and alkali are the evidence cited.
Also, the cause of the production of sound is always present in the place where there is no mind in samÄdhi. Therefore there is no contradiction with the meaning of form that is explained.
Some say:
It is called form because it transforms and obstructs.
If that is so, how can atoms transform and obstruct?
Not a single atom exists alone in the present, because it exists in an aggregate. Therefore the meaning of transforming and obstructing is established.
Some say:

There are atoms that exist alone, but they transform and obstruct without producing consciousness, because the support and object of the five consciousnesses must be an aggregate. Just as atoms are established as having no spatial dimensions, they are also without contact, but it is admitted that atoms have obstruction, resistance, and the function of obstruction.

You should know that the meaning of transforming and obstructing is also like this, because that which has ceased and that which has not yet arisen are of the same kind as it, just as fuel that is being burned and the eyes of the same kind.
Also, it is like the conventional expression:
Eating quickly and walking quickly are called a horse, but not everything is so.
Although they do not have the virtue of form, they are similar to it, and therefore the meaning of type is established.

But the name and concept are established according to a small part. This is also like this. Because of this, it also explains that the dharmas that do not arise are established as form because they abide in the characteristics of form.
Moreover, it is like the world speaking of future use in reverse, saying, If fire were to suddenly arise now, not a single thing in the village would be left.
It is also like the world speaking of past existence after the cessation of use, saying, If fire were to suddenly arise now, not a single thing in the village would be left.
That which has not yet had use and that which has already ceased using cannot truly burn, but it is reasonable to speak of them in the same way because they are similar in type.
The principle of dharmas that do not arise should also be so. If they were to arise, they should also be able to obstruct. Therefore, the explanation of obstruction establishes the meaning of form.
Although the past and future are so, what about unmanifest form?
Some explain:
Manifest form has obstruction and resistance, so unmanifest form is also called form because it follows that.
This is unreasonable, because form that accompanies mind does not arise from indication, and should not be form.

The author of the ÅšÄstra mistakenly established the former thesis here, saying that just as when a tree moves its shadow also moves, he immediately said that when the tree perishes, the shadow necessarily perishes, and when indicated form perishes, the unindicated should perish.
However, this is not like that simile, because what is established is different.

It is established that the support is called form because it has the characteristics of resistance and obstruction. This simile is said to be that the support of unindicated form is the four great elements.
When those great elements are not accomplished, the unindicated form does not necessarily cease. Therefore, there is no such fault in this case.

Moreover, this contradiction has the fault of being indefinite, because it is not definite that when this arises from that, when that perishes, this also necessarily perishes. For example, when the father, the craftsman, and the seeds, etc. perish, the son, the palace, the sprouts, etc. do not necessarily perish.

Moreover, it is like the support, which perishes when the vajra-like samÄdhi is accomplished, but the knowledge of the exhaustion of contamination that arises from it does not perish when the continuity of the aggregates is not yet exhausted.
Also, when the support of the uncontaminated is born in the upper realms, the support is destroyed but the unmanifest continues to evolve.

If the support, the primary elements, are transformed and obstructed, and the supported unmanifest is also called form, then the five sense consciousnesses are also called form because their supports, the five sense organs, are transformed and obstructed.
There is an interpretation of this statement:
There is no such fault.

When the unmanifest evolves supported by the primary elements, it is like a shadow that depends on a tree or light that depends on a jewel. The five sense consciousnesses are not like this when they depend on the five sense organs, because they can only act as conditions that assist in their generation.

The ÅšÄstra master says that the statement that the unmanifest is like a shadow that depends on a tree or light that depends on a jewel does not agree with the VaibhÄá¹£ika doctrine, because shadows, etc., are said to be colors that are subtle matter and each has its own support, the four primary elements.
This is not the opinion of the Abhidharma itself, nor is it not in agreement with the VaibhÄá¹£ika doctrine.
The meaning of this statement is that the primary elements of shadows, etc., are supported by the primary elements of trees, etc.
Why is this?
Because when the shadows, etc., are born, abide, and transform, they all follow the primary elements.
The words shadows and lights indicate a general aggregation, not just the visible form, like the words trees and jewels.

Therefore, the atoms of shadow color rely on the primary elements of shadows, etc., to arise, and the primary elements of shadows, etc., are born in reliance on the primary elements of trees, etc. Thus there is no fault of non-conformity in this case.
The author of the commentary further states:

Even if it is admitted that shadows and lights rely on trees and jewels, the manifested form is not the same as them, because it is admitted that even when the primary elements that are its support are destroyed, the manifested form does not follow them in being destroyed.
This objection is not relevant to the VibhÄá¹£Ä doctrine, because it is admitted that the support and the supported are destroyed together.
If the primary elements that are the support of the manifested form are destroyed, the manifested form that is the supported is never destroyed.
The first moment of manifested form may be destroyed together with the primary elements that are its support, but how about the manifested form of the second moment, etc.?
If the primary elements of the second moment, etc., do not exist, how can the manifested form still be present?
Although there is no mahÄbhÅ«ta in this state, the mahÄbhÅ«ta is not the support of this [form], because it is not the cause of birth.
How wonderful it is that such a good understanding of the Abhidharma!

Isn't it that the mahÄbhÅ«ta as the cause of birth is not the only support for derivative form? However, there are other mahÄbhÅ«ta as the four causes that are considered to be the support for derivative form.

If the derivative form that is supported by the mahÄbhÅ«ta as the support were not to cease when the mahÄbhÅ«ta as the support ceases, then when the noble ones are born in the formless realm, the pure derivative form that they possess should be able to manifest.
Although the pure derivative form does not function when the mahÄbhÅ«ta as the cause of birth and the mahÄbhÅ«ta as the support cease when one is born [in the formless realm],
it is known that the functioning of derivative form in the desire realm definitely does not cease due to the non-cessation of the mahÄbhÅ«ta as the support.
If it were not so, how could that be so?
For this reason, all masters have said:
All derivative form has two kinds of supports: one is the support for arising, and the other is the support for power and transformation.

When sages are born in the formless realm, they transform their support by the power of their vows, and since the four great elements do not exist there, even though they accomplish pure noninformative action, it does not actually exist.
This confusion is due to the fact that you have not yet served and honored teachers of the Abhidharma who explain it without error.
Even though the five sense organs that are the supports of eye consciousness, etc., are resistant and impeded, they are not form, because their species is different.

There is a species of consciousness that does not depend on form, namely, the five consciousnesses, which are born depending on form. The six consciousnesses all have manas as their support. Manas is also found in the formless realm.
Also, manas is found in the lower stages in such states as sleep, dreams, samÄdhi, etc., but the five organs are not found there.
Also, it is not reasonable for a single dharma, the nature of the six consciousnesses, to be both form and not form.
There is no noninformative action that does not arise in dependence on form. Therefore the support must be resistant and impeded, and the supported noninformative action is also called form.
Also, the term form is like the terms cow and peacock, which are established on the basis of a small part of the total characteristics of the thing.
It is not without distinction, so it should not be criticized.
Having explained the form aggregate, we will now explain feeling, etc.
Verse:
Feeling is the experience of contact, and conception has the nature of grasping images.
The other four are called the formation aggregate. Thus, feeling, etc., the three,
And unmanifested form and the unconditioned, are called the dharma realm and dharma sphere.
The treatise says:
The experience of contact that arises in accordance with contact, which is pleasant, unpleasant, or both, is called the feeling aggregate.
Experience is the meaning of being able to enjoy.
This is further of three kinds, namely, pleasant, painful, and neither-pleasant-nor-painful.
Because it benefits body and mind, it is called pleasant;
Because it harms body and mind, it is called painful;
That which is experienced but is neither painful nor pleasant is called neither-pleasant-nor-painful, like neither black nor white.
How do we know that this has a separate substance?
Some say:
Because they increase, decrease, and are contrary to the great elements and faculties, their three functions are distinct, and therefore we know that there are three real entities.
Some say:
Because they increase the latent tendencies of craving, hatred, and delusion, we know that there are three real entities.
Although they increase in all feelings, they are explained according to their specific characteristics in terms of their objects and associations.

Moreover, although delusion is associated with the three feelings, and craving and hatred are associated with two each, they are still said to be so in terms of the dominant and manifest associations.
Some also say that they are said to be so because their modes of activity resemble craving, hatred, and delusion.
Other masters say:

The Abhidharma says that craving increases in pleasant feeling, but it does not say that pleasant feeling only gives rise to craving; it only says that craving increases in pleasant feeling. The same should be understood for the other two feelings and hatred and delusion.
The correct explanation now is that, based on teachings and principles, we know that the third feeling definitely exists.
Teaching means, for example, saying that because of the desire to eliminate and because of the elimination of suffering, in this there is only neither-suffering-nor-happiness.
Reason means that apart from feeling, the mind must not arise, because apart from suffering and happiness, the mind can be presently obtained.
How do we know that apart from feeling, the mind must not arise?
Because it is said in the same way in various sÅ«tras.
As a sÅ«tra says:
The eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness. The union of the three is contact. Together with that, there arises feeling, conceptualization, and volition.

In the same way, up to the mind and dharmas as conditions give rise to mind consciousness. The union of the three is contact. Together with that, there arises feeling, conceptualization, and volition.
There is no seventh mind apart from feeling that arises. Therefore we know that there is definitely a third feeling.
Moreover, it is said that all feelings are briefly of two kinds:
1. grasping feelings, and 2. intrinsic nature feelings.ğŸ”½Grasping feelings refer to that which is able to experience and grasp its own object-field.
Intrinsic nature feelings refer to that which is able to experience and grasp its own accompanying contact.
Therefore the World-Honored One said:
Contact that is conducive to pleasant feeling, contact that is conducive to painful feeling, and contact that is conducive to neither painful nor pleasant feeling.
This is the meaning of contact that is experienced by pleasant feeling, etc.
It is difficult to understand the difference between feeling that experiences an object and the dharma of one-pointedness of mind, as stated in the sutra:
Fully experiencing.
This word experience seems to be used metaphorically based on wisdom, so that sutra continues later and says:
Not experiencing future existence, one truly knows.

Although one experiences and also is able to receive objects, the intrinsic nature of this experience is difficult to know, therefore feeling has the intrinsic nature of experiencing contact, this is a difference that is not shared with other [dharmas] and is easily understood.

In this way, various feelings and mind and other dharmas have the same object, because they are different from experiencing, the object of experience is different, and the object of experience is different. Because of this, when contact is experienced by feeling, at that time it is not the object;
if at that time it is the object, at that time it is not experienced, therefore the object of experience and the object of experience are different.
On the basis of this, the following passage is well interpreted:
When one experiences a pleasant feeling, one accurately knows that one is experiencing a pleasant feeling.

What is meant here is that one can use wisdom to accurately and without error know the distinctions among the three feelings. What is not pleasant is suffering, what is not suffering is pleasant, and what is neither suffering nor pleasant is neither. The same is so for the other two feelings.
Here, feeling does not refer to the intrinsic nature of feeling itself, because that is the nature of feeling itself.
It only refers to the feeling of the object and other dharmas, because all of them are what is felt by mind and mental factors.
There is a scripture that reveals this principle, as a sutra says:
There are various kinds of feelings based on various kinds of contact, and there are various kinds of craving based on various kinds of feelings.
Various kinds of elements means that the various natures and characteristics of faculties, objects, and consciousnesses have distinctions.
Why does it not say that there are various kinds of feelings based on various kinds of elements?
Why not say that various kinds of craving exist due to various kinds of elements?
This is also the same as the doubt, and therefore they should be explained together.
The order is natural and there is no error in establishing it.

It is seen in the world that when a later effect arises from a previous seed, due to differences in flowers, milk, etc., the effect has differences, just as the determination of cause and effect is established in the order of arising.

The determination of simultaneous cause and effect should also be established in the same way. Therefore, although feeling also has elements as its cause, it still necessarily uses contact as its proximate cause.
Also, just as fire is produced by rubbing two pieces of wood together, with wind as its proximate condition;
in the same way, feeling arises from the combination of the three , with contact as its proximate condition.
Therefore, in terms of experiencing contact, it is established by principle that feeling has its own nature, and does not experience the object.
This feeling is generally said to be threefold in terms of time, and is divided into six kinds in terms of the specific bases of contact.
The aggregate of feeling has been explained.

The third is the aggregate of conceptualization, which takes grasping images as its essence. It refers to the grasping of images according to their characteristics in the objects of perception, such as blue, long, etc., sounds like lute and conch, etc., fragrances like lotus and so forth, tastes like bitter and pungent, etc., tactile objects like smoothness and roughness, etc., and dharmas like arising and ceasing, etc.
Therefore, this conceptualization is named according to its function, because it is able to grasp images.
The general, specific, three, and six should be understood as in feeling.
The aggregate of conceptualization has already been explained.

The fourth is the aggregate of volitional formations, which refers to the remaining formations other than the above-mentioned three of form, feeling, and conceptualization, and other than consciousness, which will be discussed as the fourth. The remaining conditioned dharmas are named the aggregate of volitional formations.
This includes associated and non-associated dharmas, such as volition, attainment, etc., in their respective sequences.
The sutras only speak of the six groups of volition because of their supremacy.
Why is this so?
Because volition is the nature of karma, and in terms of taking karma as the cause to experience results, its power is the strongest. Therefore, the World-Honored One said:
If it is said that only that which can produce contaminated conditioned dharmas is called the aggregate of karmic forces,

if it is said that only this is called the aggregate of karmic forces, this is definitely not reasonable, because the other karmic forces are not included in form, etc., and should not be included in the aggregates.
If it is said that if it is like this, what is wrong? then it should be known that suffering and its cause are not to be eliminated.
If it is so, what is the error?
Because it contradicts the holy teachings.
As the World-Honored One said:
If one has not yet penetrated and known a single dharma, I say that one cannot put an end to suffering. The same is said for what has not yet been eliminated and extinguished.

If it is said that the other karmic forces are like space and non-analytical cessation, and there is no error in this, the reasoning is also not so, because they are the causes for the increase of grasping the self, and grasping the self is able to obstruct the dharma of the end of suffering.
The elder says:
The aggregate of karmic forces is only volition, and the other mental factors such as attention are distinctions of volition.
He also says:

The activities of attention, etc., cannot be apart from thought and known to have a separate substance, nor can a small part of the substance of thought be apprehended apart from the other activities.
Consequently, although the aggregate of activity is not a single thing, it is included in a single thought. Therefore, although a scripture mentions a single thought, this does not contradict reason.
How do we know that attention, etc., all have thought as their substance?
Because the BhagavÄn said in a scripture that the six groups of thought are the aggregate of activity. He also said that craving, hatred, etc., are mental activity.
He said that neither black nor white action that has neither pleasure nor pain as its ripening can exhaust all action, because it is said that this is called thought and is the holy path.

He said that the various contemplations, the immeasurables, and the formlessnesses are white actions with white ripening. It is not necessary to say that a different dharma is meant by a different name, and it is not a mistake to say that one is many.
The various BhagavÄns never make mistakes.
The theory of the Sthavira is like this, but reason is not thus, because the various positions established are mutually contradictory.
The former passage says that the aggregate of karmic forces is volition alone, while the latter passage says that the aggregate of karmic forces is not a single thing.
How can it be that a single volition is not a single thing?
Because it is said that the six volitions are the aggregate of karmic forces.
The reason that it is known that attention, etc., have volition as their substance is not correct, because the names of dharmas are different.

It is seen in the scriptures that the World Honored One speaks of dharmas in various ways, sometimes including the later in the earlier, sometimes including the earlier in the later, sometimes including the middle by the earlier and later, and sometimes including the earlier and later by the middle.
In which scriptures does he include the later in the earlier?
It refers to the scriptures on the meditative absorptions, nutriments, the Koá¹­ikará¹‡a, the Dharma of non-retrogression, the truth of origination, and so forth.
The meditative absorptions are the four cultivations of samÄdhi.
The scriptures say:
If one cultivates the first meditative absorption, one attains abiding in present happiness.
Others do not attain abiding in present happiness. This is said by including the later in the earlier. Therefore, this is the TathÄgata's teaching without reduction.
Food refers to the four kinds of food. A sutra says:
The first section of food has coarse and fine.
It is not that the other three foods do not have coarse and fine, but this is said in order to take the first and include the later.
Gautama, it means that the sutra says that one does not understand form, not the other four aggregates.
It is already understood, but this is said in order to take the first and include the later.
The Dharma of non-retrogression, it means that the sutra says:
A person who has attained the fruit of stream-entry does not fall into evil realms.
It is not that other noble ones fall into evil realms, but this is said in order to take the first and include the later.
The truth of origination, it means that the sutra says craving is the truth of origination.
It is not that other defiled dharmas are not included in the truth of origination, but this is said in order to take the first and include the later.
This will be specifically shown in the contemplation of the truths.
All such innumerable sutras take the first to include the later. For this reason, the Tathagata's teachings are not diminished.
In which sutras does taking the later include the first?
Namely, the sutras on obtaining one's own body, abodes of consciousness, praising and extolling the field of merit, and so forth.
As for obtaining one's own body, the Sutra on the Four Attainments of One's Own Body states:
Being born in the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception, one cannot harm oneself or be harmed by others.
It is not that all the formless heavens cannot harm themselves or be harmed by others. This is said in order to include the latter and the former.
As for the abodes of consciousness, the Sutra on the Seven Abodes of Consciousness states:
There are sentient beings with form, with a single body and different perceptions, like the Heaven of Extreme Radiance, which is the third abode of consciousness.

It is not that the heavens of Lesser Radiance and Immeasurable Radiance are also called having form, a single body and different perceptions. This is said in order to include the latter and the former.
As for praising and extolling the field of merit, that sutra states:
If one always makes wonderful offerings to the arhats,
The various celestial beings will always praise and present auspicious omens.

It is not that the merit of the wonderful giving cultivated in the first three does not receive praise and auspicious signs from the gods, etc. This is said in order to include the beginning by citing the end.
If it is said that the first three are also called arhats because they are worthy of offerings, then this sutra would not be definitive in meaning, because the name arhat is the master of the adepts.
In which sutras is the middle included by citing only the beginning and end?
It refers to the sutras praising going forth and the purities, etc.
The praise of going forth refers to that sutra which says:
Those who have gone forth as renunciant practitioners, who can realize the fruit of stream-entry,
and the fruit of arhatship, are said to have done much.

It is not that renunciant practitioners who realize the fruit of once-returning and the fruit of non-returning have not done much. This is said in order to include the middle by citing only the beginning and end.
The praise of the purities refers to that sutra which says:
Those who abide in marvelous faith in the TathÄgata, unshakable,
And with pure precepts, one always encounters auspicious signs.

It is not that one who abides in faith in the Dharma and Saá¹…gha without wavering will not encounter auspicious signs, but it is said in this way in order to include the middle by mentioning the beginning and end.
In which sÅ«tras is the middle mentioned in order to include the beginning and end?
It is said in the sÅ«tras:
If one cultivates the fourth dhyÄna, it is called attaining the destruction of defilements.
It is not that one who does not rely on the seven [stages] is unable to destroy defilements, but it is said in this way in order to include the beginning and end by mentioning the middle.
There are innumerable sÅ«tras like this, all of which include the beginning and end by mentioning the middle. For this reason, the TathÄgata's teachings are not diminished.
Since the sÅ«tras are like this, this [Abhidharma] should also be so.
Although the aggregate of volition is composed of many dharmas, there is no fault in mentioning only the beginning.
Why not mention the initial mental orientation, etc., which create the conditioned, since volition is supreme, like the mind which leads, manifests in three places, cultivates two dharmas, etc.?
As for the mind being the guide, a sutra says:
The mind guides the world.
Here, although there are dharmas such as feeling and conceptualization, it is said in this way because the mind is superior.
The three places being present, as a sutra says:
Because faith is present in three places, it can give rise to much merit.
Here, although there are dharmas such as non-greed, non-hatred, and right view, it is said in this way because faith is superior.
Cultivating the two dharmas, as a sutra says:
One should cultivate two dharmas, namely samatha and vipasyana.
All wholesome conditioned dharmas should be cultivated, but it is said in this way because samatha and vipasyana are superior.
These sutras all take the superior dharmas as the first, and this should be so as well.

Moreover, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, has remaining teachings that can be found everywhere, such as stupas, the destinies of good people, the liberation of the mind, and the sutras on severing the bonds.
As for stupas, a sutra says:
The stupas of these three types of people should be built.
This principle should not be applied to stupas for ordinary beings.
Those who have not seen the truths, it should be understood that this sutra is a partial statement.
As for the term good persons, as a sutra says:
The seven good persons are those who progress to nirvana, the fruit of arhatship.
It is not the case that other noble ones are not good persons. It should be understood that this sutra is a partial statement.
As for liberation of the mind, as a sutra says:
Having attained arhatship, one's mind is liberated from the defilements of desire, the defilements of existence, and the defilements of ignorance.
However, in reality one is liberated from all afflictions and secondary afflictions. It should be understood that this sutra is a partial statement.
As for cutting off the bonds, as a sutra says:
Permanently cutting off the three bonds, one realizes the fruit of stream-entry.
It is not the case that one does not permanently cut off all afflictions that are eliminated by seeing the truths. It should be understood that this sutra is a partial statement.
Such sutras all speak from the perspective of superiority. This is also like that, because the function of creating conditioned phenomena is superior.
How is it said that this creates conditioned phenomena?
It means that it has the superior ability to attract and produce effects.
Although effects originally exist, a small part is produced, and this is able to attract them, so it is established as creation.
The elder's statement:
Creating conditioned phenomena means that volition can create conditioned phenomena that did not previously exist.
Like a weaver says:
I use these threads to weave and make garments.
This should also be so.
Such statements are definitely unreasonable, because the dharma of dependence and non-dependence is different.
Their intention is that volition is like the weaver, and conditioned phenomena that did not previously exist are like garments. The threads that are the basis of garments have no analogy.
If it is admitted that the substance of future conditioned phenomena exists and has a small part of function, the meaning of creation can be established.
The elder's analogy of threads shows that there is a future, or the analogy established has words but no meaning.
The Abhidharma masters say that the analogy is appropriate for nominally existent dharmas that did not exist previously but now exist.
If you insist that real substance also did not exist previously, then you should not establish this analogy.
They should also explain the difference between the nominal and the real. If there is a difference, then there is no analogy. If there is no difference, then it is like a flower in the sky.
The reason that greed, anger, etc. are called mental actions is because they are the essence of volition. This is also unreasonable.
Although the substance of greed, anger, and wrong views is not action, because they are the provisions for action, they are also called action, just as other provisions are also called that.
As the Sutra on Moral Conduct says:
Seeing the joy of the assembly, the joy of the steps of the river of sages.
Because that joy is a provision, it is also called joy.
Also, as a sutra says:
If the eye faculty is undisciplined and unprotected, this dharma can lead to undesirable karmic retribution.
Although the eye faculty is a dharma without karmic retribution, because it is a provision for undesirable karmic retribution, it is also said to be able to lead to undesirable karmic retribution.
Also, as a scripture says:
The five kinds of equipment for regression, such as delight in conversation, etc.
The true equipment for regression refers to the afflictions, because they cause one to regress from the fruits.
Delight in conversation, etc. are the provisions for that, and are also called equipment for regression.
Also, as a scripture says:
Fools attached to desires give rise to disputes, while sages, being free from desires, are free from disputes.
Therefore one should eliminate all desires, like the unicorn roaming alone.
Being attached to objects gives rise to disputes. Objects are not really desires, but because they are provisions for desire, they are also called desires.
Therefore a scripture says:
The wonderful objects of the world are not true desires; true desires refer to the discriminating craving of people.
Also, as a scripture says:
Increasing the latent tendencies of form.
Form is not the latent tendencies, but because it is the provisions for that, it is spoken of in the same way.
Also, as a scripture says:
Women are the defilement of pure conduct, women harm and injure sentient beings.
The woman is not really defilement, but defilement, such as craving, is called defilement because it is the equipment of defilement.
Also, a scripture declares seven leaks, but in reality there are only two, and the rest are not leaks but are called leaks because they are the equipment of leaks.

On the basis of these and other scriptures, it is proven by reason that craving, hatred, etc., are called mental actions because they are the equipment of mental actions and are not the substance of actions.
Action that is neither black nor white and has no retribution can exhaust all action, because it is said to be the holy path and is called volition.

The idea that it is known that attention, etc., are volition by nature is also unreasonable, because there is no error in calling them by the name of one of their components, as in the case of thought.
A scripture says,
Cultivating the notion of impermanence can eliminate craving for desire, form, and non-form.
It calls the holy path by the name of notion.
Since it is admitted that the holy path is not a kind of notion, the same is true of this, and there is no error.
Also, it is said that feeling and attention can eliminate the passions, because a scripture says,
Cultivating the factor of joy, based on a mind free from craving, can destroy the nest.
Since the noble path is not a distinction in the nature of feeling, this is also so, and therefore there is no error.
There are those who hear the sutras say that karma binds sentient beings, meaning that all karma can bind.
In order to eliminate such mistaken attachments, it is said that this thought karma can exhaust all karma.

It is also said in this way in order to show the superiority of karma, as it is said that the various meditations, immeasurables, and formless [absorptions] are white-white karmas with ripened results.

Those who know that thought and attention, etc., take thought as their essence, this is not a careful examination, because the various meditations, etc., take the five aggregates and four aggregates as their intrinsic nature.
As a sutra says:
Herein, all that is form, all that is feeling, and so on, up to being called meditation, etc.

The VaibhÄá¹£ikas do not say that karma has the nature of form, in order to show that among all karmas, it is the strongest in attracting ripened results, therefore, all wholesome five-aggregate dharmas are said to be karmas here.
Also, in this context, feeling, conceptualization, and consciousness are said to be karmic acts, but their substance is not volition.
In the same way, in this context, attention and other dharmas are also said to be karmic acts, but their substance is not volition.
If it is said that there is no error because feeling, etc. are categorized as separate aggregates, then it is established that different names can be used to refer to different dharmas.
Since this is established, the above statement that greed, hatred, etc. are called mental karmic acts because they are volition is not established.
It is clearly seen that established different things such as feeling, etc. are referred to by the term karmic act. The same should be true for other dharmas.
This refutes the later reason given, that different dharmas cannot be referred to by different names.
Also, it is seen that different names can refer to different dharmas, such as saying one practices the giving of fragrance, etc.

The substance of giving is volition, not fragrance, etc. However, because fragrance, etc. give rise to volition, there are different names referring to different dharmas. It is not a mistaken statement to say one is the other, so the Blessed Ones never make mistaken statements.

The assertion that attention, etc., are by nature volition is also unreasonable, because it is said in terms of the preeminent, because the relationship of name and substance is not fixed, because the inclinations of sentient beings to be converted differ, because it is possible to find explicit statements in the scriptures, and because the Lord would not speak erroneously.

If you maintain that the substance of the aggregate of karmic forces is only volition, then you are revealing that the words of the World Honored One are erroneous, because you admit that the World Honored One said that the substance of one dharma is not one, and that what is not one is one.
If you say that the aggregate of karmic forces is not composed of one substance, then you are revealing that the words of the World Honored One are not erroneous.
Therefore, your reason is not established.

Also, your theory contradicts our inferences, because the substance of the aggregate of karmic forces is not only volition, because it is established as a general concept, like the sphere of the dharmas and the element of the dharmas.
If it were otherwise, it would be called only volition, because it is composed of one dharma, like the aggregates of feeling and conceptualization.

The meaning here is that, just as the term â€œdharmaâ€ is generally used to refer to the sixth sense base, the sixth sense object, and the sixth sense consciousness, and thus generally includes the eleven sense bases and the seventeen sense elements, but does not include many dharmas,

in the same way, the term â€œactivityâ€ is generally used to refer to the four aggregates, and thus generally includes the four aggregates, but does not include many activities. Therefore we know that the substance of the aggregate of activity is not only volition.

If this is so, then, like the other aggregates, it should be mentioned last. This will be shown in the discussion of the order of the aggregates. This is not the proper place to discuss this matter, so we should stop here.
Also, because the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya uses the plantain tree as a metaphor for the aggregate of activity, we know that the substance of the aggregate of activity is not only volition.
It is said that the aggregate of activity is like a plantain tree, which shows that many things make up the substance of the aggregate of activity.
Also, because a sÅ«tra passage speaks of association, we know that the substance of the aggregate of activity is not only volition.
As a sÅ«tra passage says:
Seeing is the root, and faith and knowledge are associated with the characteristics of proof.
If faith and knowledge are both volition, then the substance of volition would be associated with volition.
It is not reasonable to allow that a thing is associated with itself.
Also, attention and so on should not be the distinctions of intention, because in the scriptures, apart from attention and so on, intention is separately mentioned.
As a scripture teaches:
He sees in this way and thinks in this way.
If wrong views are identical to intention, this meaning should be expressed as:
He thinks in this way and thinks in this way, or he sees in this way and sees in this way.
If this is said, what is the difference in meaning?
Also, as a scripture teaches:
He has such faith, desire, effort, tranquility, mindfulness, wisdom, intention, and equanimity, which are called superior practices.
If faith and so on are the practices that are intention, then after faith and so on are mentioned, why is intention mentioned again?
Also, these dharmas seem to function simultaneously. How can many substances of a single intention arise together?
The elder explains this as follows:
In order to include the other practices that arise at this time, intention is again mentioned.
The former explanation of faith, etc., is given in order to show the superior practices that arise at this time, just as the five impure dharmas and the four practices are explained.
That is, although views are a form of defilement among the five impure dharmas, they are explained separately because they are the most important.
The four practices are as stated in a scripture:
Cultivate good conduct of body, speech, and mind, and right views, and eliminate bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, and wrong views.
Right and wrong views are not included in good and bad conduct of mind, but are explained separately because they are superior. This should be the same.
This is not reasonable, because faith, etc., should also be included in thought, and should not be explained separately.
Haven't we already said that faith, etc., are explained in order to show the superior practices that arise at this time?
Although we know this has already been said, it is still unreasonable, because one dharma cannot arise simultaneously with many substances, like feeling, conceptualization, etc.

It is unreasonable, therefore feeling, conceptualization, etc., cannot have the same substance as one dharma category, and pleasure, etc., must be separate and arise simultaneously. Therefore their explanation is not the Buddhist teaching.
Moreover, if thought is not mentioned in each case, the scriptures would be incomplete.
As the World-Honored One said:
The precepts, concentration, wisdom, and liberation of learners and post-learners.
Since thought is not mentioned in this scripture, it should be added to the other mental factors such as attention.
If it is said that the listener already knows them, then mentioning wisdom and so forth would also be useless.
Therefore, their explanation is definitely unreasonable, and the analogy is also illogical, because those who hold views are difficult to liberate.
In order to show that the meaning of being bound by various views is firm and strong, the faults of afflictions are shown in general and in detail.
